param.name: EK3_RNG_USE_SPD
param.documentation: The range finder will not be used as the primary height source when the horizontal ground speed is greater than this value.

param.name: EK3_ACC_BIAS_LIM
param.documentation: The accelerometer bias state will be limited to +- this value

param.humanName: Bitmask of active EKF cores that will always use heading fusion
param.name: EK3_MAG_MASK
param.documentation: 1 byte bitmap of EKF cores that will disable magnetic field states and use simple magnetic heading fusion at all times. This parameter enables specified cores to be used as a backup for flight into an environment with high levels of external magnetic interference which may degrade the EKF attitude estimate when using 3-axis magnetometer fusion. NOTE : Use of a different magnetometer fusion algorithm on different cores makes unwanted EKF core switches due to magnetometer errors more likely.

param.humanName: Bitmask control of EKF reference height correction
param.name: EK3_OGN_HGT_MASK
param.documentation: When a height sensor other than GPS is used as the primary height source by the EKF, the position of the zero height datum is defined by that sensor and its frame of reference. If a GPS height measurement is also available, then the height of the WGS-84 height datum used by the EKF can be corrected so that the height returned by the getLLH() function is compensated for primary height sensor drift and change in datum over time. The first two bit positions control when the height datum will be corrected. Correction is performed using a Bayes filter and only operates when GPS quality permits. The third bit position controls where the corrections to the GPS reference datum are applied. Corrections can be applied to the local vertical position or to the reported EKF origin height (default).
param.field: 0:Correct when using Baro height,1:Correct when using range finder height,2:Apply corrections to local position

param.name: EK3_VIS_VERR_MIN
param.documentation: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when maximum quality is reported by the sensor. When quality is between max and min, the error will be calculated using linear interpolation between VIS_VERR_MIN and VIS_VERR_MAX.

param.name: EK3_VIS_VERR_MAX
param.documentation: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when minimum quality is reported by the sensor. When quality is between max and min, the error will be calculated using linear interpolation between VIS_VERR_MIN and VIS_VERR_MAX.

param.name: EK3_WENC_VERR
param.documentation: This is the 1-STD odometry velocity observation error that will be assumed when wheel encoder data is being fused.

param.name: FENCE_ENABLE
param.documentation: Allows you to enable (1) or disable (0) the fence functionality

param.name: FENCE_TYPE
param.documentation: Enabled fence types held as bitmask

param.name: FENCE_ACTION
param.documentation: What action should be taken when fence is breached

param.name: FENCE_ALT_MAX
param.documentation: Maximum altitude allowed before geofence triggers

param.name: FENCE_RADIUS
param.documentation: Circle fence radius which when breached will cause an RTL

param.name: FENCE_MARGIN
param.documentation: Distance that autopilot's should maintain from the fence to avoid a breach

param.name: FENCE_TOTAL
param.documentation: Number of polygon points saved in eeprom (do not update manually)

param.name: FENCE_ALT_MIN
param.documentation: Minimum altitude allowed before geofence triggers

param.name: GND_ABS_PRESS
param.documentation: calibrated ground pressure in Pascals

param.name: GND_TEMP
param.documentation: User provided ambient ground temperature in degrees Celsius. This is used to improve the calculation of the altitude the vehicle is at. This parameter is not persistent and will be reset to 0 every time the vehicle is rebooted. A value of 0 means use the internal measurement ambient temperature.

param.name: GND_ALT_OFFSET
param.documentation: altitude offset in meters added to barometric altitude. This is used to allow for automatic adjustment of the base barometric altitude by a ground station equipped with a barometer. The value is added to the barometric altitude read by the aircraft. It is automatically reset to 0 when the barometer is calibrated on each reboot or when a preflight calibration is performed.

param.name: GND_PRIMARY
param.documentation: This selects which barometer will be the primary if multiple barometers are found

param.name: GND_EXT_BUS
param.documentation: This selects the bus number for looking for an I2C barometer

param.name: GND_SPEC_GRAV
param.documentation: This sets the specific gravity of the fluid when flying an underwater ROV.

param.name: GND_ABS_PRESS2
param.documentation: calibrated ground pressure in Pascals

param.name: GND_ABS_PRESS3
param.documentation: calibrated ground pressure in Pascals

param.humanName: Range in which sample is accepted
param.name: GND_FLTR_RNG
param.documentation: This sets the range around the average value that new samples must be within to be accepted. This can help reduce the impact of noise on sensors that are on long I2C cables. The value is a percentage from the average value. A value of zero disables this filter.

param.name: GPS_TYPE
param.documentation: GPS type

param.name: GPS_TYPE2
param.documentation: GPS type of 2nd GPS

param.name: GPS_NAVFILTER
param.documentation: Navigation filter engine setting

param.name: GPS_AUTO_SWITCH
param.documentation: Automatic switchover to GPS reporting best lock

param.humanName: Minimum Lock Type Accepted for DGPS
param.name: GPS_MIN_DGPS
param.documentation: Sets the minimum type of differential GPS corrections required before allowing to switch into DGPS mode.

param.name: GPS_SBAS_MODE
param.documentation: This sets the SBAS (satellite based augmentation system) mode if available on this GPS. If set to 2 then the SBAS mode is not changed in the GPS. Otherwise the GPS will be reconfigured to enable/disable SBAS. Disabling SBAS may be worthwhile in some parts of the world where an SBAS signal is available but the baseline is too long to be useful.

param.name: GPS_MIN_ELEV
param.documentation: This sets the minimum elevation of satellites above the horizon for them to be used for navigation. Setting this to -100 leaves the minimum elevation set to the GPS modules default.

param.name: GPS_INJECT_TO
param.documentation: The GGS can send raw serial packets to inject data to multiple GPSes.

param.name: GPS_SBP_LOGMASK
param.documentation: Masked with the SBP msg_type field to determine whether SBR1/SBR2 data is logged

param.name: GPS_RAW_DATA
param.documentation: Handles logging raw data; on uBlox chips that support raw data this will log RXM messages into dataflash log; on Septentrio this will log on the equipment's SD card and when set to 2, the autopilot will try to stop logging after disarming and restart after arming

values.value: Only log every five samples (uBlox only)

param.name: GPS_GNSS_MODE
param.documentation: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the first GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

param.name: GPS_SAVE_CFG
param.documentation: Determines whether the configuration for this GPS should be written to non-volatile memory on the GPS. Currently working for UBlox 6 series and above.

param.name: GPS_GNSS_MODE2
param.documentation: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the second GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

param.name: GPS_AUTO_CONFIG
param.documentation: Controls if the autopilot should automatically configure the GPS based on the parameters and default settings

param.name: GPS_RATE_MS
param.documentation: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz is not allowed

param.name: GPS_RATE_MS2
param.documentation: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz is not allowed

param.name: GPS_POS1_X
param.documentation: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_POS1_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_POS1_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_POS2_X
param.documentation: X position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_POS2_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_POS2_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

param.name: GPS_DELAY_MS
param.documentation: Controls the amount of GPS measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

param.name: GPS_DELAY_MS2
param.documentation: Controls the amount of GPS measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

param.name: GPS_BLEND_MASK
param.documentation: Determines which of the accuracy measures Horizontal position, Vertical Position and Speed are used to calculate the weighting on each GPS receiver when soft switching has been selected by setting GPS_AUTO_SWITCH to 2

param.name: GPS_BLEND_TC
param.documentation: Controls the slowest time constant applied to the calculation of GPS position and height offsets used to adjust different GPS receivers for steady state position differences.

param.name: INS_GYROFFS_X
param.documentation: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYROFFS_Y
param.documentation: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYROFFS_Z
param.documentation: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR2OFFS_X
param.documentation: Gyro2 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR2OFFS_Y
param.documentation: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR2OFFS_Z
param.documentation: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR3OFFS_X
param.documentation: Gyro3 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR3OFFS_Y
param.documentation: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_GYR3OFFS_Z
param.documentation: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

param.name: INS_ACCSCAL_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACCSCAL_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACCSCAL_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACCOFFS_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACCOFFS_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACCOFFS_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC2SCAL_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC2SCAL_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC2SCAL_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC2OFFS_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC2OFFS_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC2OFFS_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer2 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC3SCAL_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC3SCAL_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC3SCAL_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS_ACC3OFFS_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC3OFFS_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_ACC3OFFS_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS_GYRO_FILTER
param.documentation: Filter cutoff frequency for gyroscopes. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

param.name: INS_ACCEL_FILTER
param.documentation: Filter cutoff frequency for accelerometers. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

param.humanName: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
param.name: INS_USE
param.documentation: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

param.humanName: Use second IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
param.name: INS_USE2
param.documentation: Use second IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

param.humanName: Use third IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
param.name: INS_USE3
param.documentation: Use third IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

param.humanName: Stillness threshold for detecting if we are moving
param.name: INS_STILL_THRESH
param.documentation: Threshold to tolerate vibration to determine if vehicle is motionless. This depends on the frame type and if there is a constant vibration due to motors before launch or after landing. Total motionless is about 0.05. Suggested values: Planes/rover use 0.1, multirotors use 1, tradHeli uses 5

param.name: INS_GYR_CAL
param.documentation: Conrols when automatic gyro calibration is performed

param.name: INS_TRIM_OPTION
param.documentation: Specifies how the accel cal routine determines the trims

values.value: Assume ACC_BODYFIX is perfectly aligned to the vehicle

param.name: INS_ACC_BODYFIX
param.documentation: The body-fixed accelerometer to be used for trim calculation

param.name: INS_POS1_X
param.documentation: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_POS1_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_POS1_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_POS2_X
param.documentation: X position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_POS3_X
param.documentation: X position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.documentation: Y position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_GYR_ID
param.documentation: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS_GYR2_ID
param.documentation: Gyro2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS_GYR3_ID
param.documentation: Gyro3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS_ACC_ID
param.documentation: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS_ACC3_ID
param.documentation: Accelerometer3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS_FAST_SAMPLE
param.documentation: Mask of IMUs to enable fast sampling on, if available

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_CNT
param.documentation: Number of samples to take when logging streams of IMU sensor readings. Will be rounded down to a multiple of 32.

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_MASK
param.documentation: Bitmap of which IMUs to log batch data for

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_OPT
param.documentation: Options for the BatchSampler
param.field: 0:Sensor-Rate Logging (sample at full sensor rate seen by AP)

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN
param.documentation: Interval between pushing samples to the DataFlash log

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGCT
param.documentation: Number of samples to push to count every INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN

param.name: INS_NOTCH_ENABLE
param.documentation: Enable notch filter

param.name: INS_NOTCH_FREQ
param.documentation: Notch center frequency in Hz

param.name: INS_NOTCH_BW
param.documentation: Notch bandwidth in Hz

param.name: INS_NOTCH_ATT
param.documentation: Notch attenuation in dB

param.name: LOG_BACKEND_TYPE
param.documentation: 0 for None, 1 for File, 2 for dataflash mavlink, 3 for both file and dataflash

param.humanName: Maximum DataFlash File Backend buffer size (in kilobytes)
param.name: LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE
param.documentation: The DataFlash_File backend uses a buffer to store data before writing to the block device. Raising this value may reduce "gaps" in your SD card logging. This buffer size may be reduced depending on available memory. PixHawk requires at least 4 kilobytes. Maximum value available here is 64 kilobytes.

param.name: LOG_DISARMED
param.documentation: If LOG_DISARMED is set to 1 then logging will be enabled while disarmed. This can make for very large logfiles but can help a lot when tracking down startup issues

param.humanName: Enable logging of information needed for Replay
param.name: LOG_REPLAY
param.documentation: If LOG_REPLAY is set to 1 then the EKF2 state estimator will log detailed information needed for diagnosing problems with the Kalman filter. It is suggested that you also raise LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE to give more buffer space for logging and use a high quality microSD card to ensure no sensor data is lost

param.humanName: Stop logging to current file on disarm
param.name: LOG_FILE_DSRMROT
param.documentation: When set, the current log file is closed when the vehicle is disarmed. If LOG_DISARMED is set then a fresh log will be opened.

param.humanName: Maximum DataFlash MAVLink Backend buffer size
param.name: LOG_MAV_BUFSIZE
param.documentation: Maximum amount of memory to allocate to DataFlash-over-mavlink

param.name: MIS_TOTAL
param.documentation: The number of mission mission items that has been loaded by the ground station. Do not change this manually.

param.humanName: Mission Restart when entering Auto mode
param.name: MIS_RESTART
param.documentation: Controls mission starting point when entering Auto mode (either restart from beginning of mission or resume from last command run)

param.name: MIS_OPTIONS
param.documentation: Bitmask of what options to use in missions.

param.name: MNT_RC_IN_ROLL
param.documentation: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control roll movements

param.name: MNT_ANGMIN_ROL
param.documentation: Minimum physical roll angular position of mount.

param.name: MNT_ANGMAX_ROL
param.documentation: Maximum physical roll angular position of the mount

param.name: MNT_RC_IN_TILT
param.documentation: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control tilt (pitch) movements

param.name: MNT_ANGMIN_TIL
param.documentation: Minimum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of mount.

param.name: MNT_ANGMAX_TIL
param.documentation: Maximum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of the mount

param.name: MNT_RC_IN_PAN
param.documentation: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control pan (yaw) movements

param.name: MNT_ANGMIN_PAN
param.documentation: Minimum physical pan (yaw) angular position of mount.

param.name: MNT_ANGMAX_PAN
param.documentation: Maximum physical pan (yaw) angular position of the mount

param.name: MNT_JSTICK_SPD
param.documentation: 0 for position control, small for low speeds, 100 for max speed. A good general value is 10 which gives a movement speed of 3 degrees per second.

param.name: MNT_LEAD_RLL
param.documentation: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

param.name: MNT_LEAD_PTCH
param.documentation: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

param.documentation: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

param.name: MNT2_TYPE
param.documentation: Mount Type (None, Servo or MAVLink)

param.name: MOT_PWM_TYPE
param.documentation: This selects the output PWM type as regular PWM, OneShot, Brushed motor support using PWM (duty cycle) with separated direction signal, Brushed motor support with separate throttle and direction PWM (duty cyle)

param.humanName: Motor Output PWM freq for brushed motors
param.name: MOT_PWM_FREQ
param.documentation: Motor Output PWM freq for brushed motors

param.humanName: Motor PWM output disabled when disarmed
param.name: MOT_SAFE_DISARM
param.documentation: Disables motor PWM output when disarmed

param.name: MOT_THR_MIN
param.documentation: Throttle minimum percentage the autopilot will apply. This is useful for handling a deadzone around low throttle and for preventing internal combustion motors cutting out during missions.

param.name: MOT_THR_MAX
param.documentation: Throttle maximum percentage the autopilot will apply. This can be used to prevent overheating an ESC or motor on an electric rover

param.name: MOT_SLEWRATE
param.documentation: Throttle slew rate as a percentage of total range per second. A value of 100 allows the motor to change over its full range in one second. A value of zero disables the limit. Note some NiMH powered rovers require a lower setting of 40 to reduce current demand to avoid brownouts.

param.name: MOT_THST_EXPO
param.documentation: Thrust curve exponent (-1 to +1 with 0 being linear)

param.name: MOT_VEC_THR_BASE
param.documentation: Throttle level above which steering is scaled down when using vector thrust. zero to disable vectored thrust

param.name: MOT_SPD_SCA_BASE
param.documentation: Speed above which steering is scaled down when using regular steering/throttle vehicles. zero to disable speed scaling

param.name: NAVL1_PERIOD
param.documentation: Period in seconds of L1 tracking loop. This parameter is the primary control for agressiveness of turns in auto mode. This needs to be larger for less responsive airframes. The default of 20 is quite conservative, but for most RC aircraft will lead to reasonable flight. For smaller more agile aircraft a value closer to 15 is appropriate, or even as low as 10 for some very agile aircraft. When tuning, change this value in small increments, as a value that is much too small (say 5 or 10 below the right value) can lead to very radical turns, and a risk of stalling.

param.name: NAVL1_DAMPING
param.documentation: Damping ratio for L1 control. Increase this in increments of 0.05 if you are getting overshoot in path tracking. You should not need a value below 0.7 or above 0.85.

param.name: NAVL1_XTRACK_I
param.documentation: Crosstrack error integrator gain. This gain is applied to the crosstrack error to ensure it converges to zero. Set to zero to disable. Smaller values converge slower, higher values will cause crosstrack error oscillation.

param.name: NAVL1_LIM_BANK
param.documentation: The sealevel bank angle limit for a continous loiter. (Used to calculate airframe loading limits at higher altitudes). Setting to 0, will instead just scale the loiter radius directly

param.name: NTF_LED_BRIGHT
param.documentation: Select the RGB LED brightness level. When USB is connected brightness will never be higher than low regardless of the setting.

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_ENABLE
param.documentation: Enable or disable the buzzer. Only for Linux and PX4 based boards.

param.name: NTF_LED_OVERRIDE
param.documentation: This sets up the board RGB LED for override by MAVLink. Normal notify LED control is disabled

param.name: NTF_DISPLAY_TYPE
param.documentation: This sets up the type of on-board I2C display. Disabled by default.

param.name: NTF_OREO_THEME
param.documentation: Enable/Disable Solo Oreo LED driver, 0 to disable, 1 for Aircraft theme, 2 for Rover theme

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_PIN
param.documentation: Enables to connect active buzzer to arbitrary pin. Requires 3-pin buzzer or additional MOSFET!

param.name: PRX_TYPE
param.documentation: What type of proximity sensor is connected

param.name: PRX_ORIENT
param.documentation: Proximity sensor orientation

param.name: PRX_YAW_CORR
param.documentation: Proximity sensor yaw correction

param.name: PRX_IGN_ANG1
param.documentation: Proximity sensor ignore angle 1

param.name: PRX_IGN_WID1
param.documentation: Proximity sensor ignore width 1

param.name: PRX_IGN_ANG2
param.documentation: Proximity sensor ignore angle 2

param.name: PRX_IGN_WID2

param.name: RCMAP_ROLL
param.documentation: Roll channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Roll is normally on channel 1, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_PITCH
param.documentation: Pitch channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Pitch is normally on channel 2, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_THROTTLE
param.documentation: Throttle channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Throttle is normally on channel 3, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Warning APM 2.X: Changing the throttle channel could produce unexpected fail-safe results if connection between receiver and on-board PPM Encoder is lost. Disabling on-board PPM Encoder is recommended. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_YAW
param.documentation: Yaw channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Yaw (also known as rudder) is normally on channel 4, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_FORWARD
param.documentation: Forward channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Forward is normally on channel 5, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_LATERAL
param.documentation: Lateral channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Lateral is normally on channel 6, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RELAY_PIN
param.documentation: Digital pin number for first relay control. This is the pin used for camera control.

param.name: RELAY_PIN2
param.documentation: Digital pin number for 2nd relay control.

param.name: RELAY_PIN3
param.documentation: Digital pin number for 3rd relay control.

param.name: RELAY_PIN4
param.documentation: Digital pin number for 4th relay control.

param.name: RELAY_DEFAULT
param.documentation: The state of the relay on boot.

param.name: RNGFND_TYPE
param.documentation: What type of rangefinder device that is connected

param.name: RNGFND_PIN
param.documentation: Analog pin that rangefinder is connected to. Set this to 0..9 for the APM2 analog pins. Set to 64 on an APM1 for the dedicated 'airspeed' port on the end of the board. Set to 11 on PX4 for the analog 'airspeed' port. Set to 15 on the Pixhawk for the analog 'airspeed' port.

param.name: RNGFND_SCALING
param.documentation: Scaling factor between rangefinder reading and distance. For the linear and inverted functions this is in meters per volt. For the hyperbolic function the units are meterVolts.

param.name: RNGFND_OFFSET
param.documentation: Offset in volts for zero distance for analog rangefinders. Offset added to distance in centimeters for PWM and I2C Lidars

param.name: RNGFND_FUNCTION
param.documentation: Control over what function is used to calculate distance. For a linear function, the distance is (voltage-offset)*scaling. For a inverted function the distance is (offset-voltage)*scaling. For a hyperbolic function the distance is scaling/(voltage-offset). The functions return the distance in meters.

param.name: RNGFND_MIN_CM
param.documentation: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

param.name: RNGFND_MAX_CM
param.documentation: Maximum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

param.name: RNGFND_STOP_PIN
param.documentation: Digital pin that enables/disables rangefinder measurement for an analog rangefinder. A value of -1 means no pin. If this is set, then the pin is set to 1 to enable the rangefinder and set to 0 to disable it. This can be used to ensure that multiple sonar rangefinders don't interfere with each other.

param.name: RNGFND_SETTLE
param.documentation: The time in milliseconds that the rangefinder reading takes to settle. This is only used when a STOP_PIN is specified. It determines how long we have to wait for the rangefinder to give a reading after we set the STOP_PIN high. For a sonar rangefinder with a range of around 7m this would need to be around 50 milliseconds to allow for the sonar pulse to travel to the target and back again.

param.name: RNGFND_RMETRIC
param.documentation: This parameter sets whether an analog rangefinder is ratiometric. Most analog rangefinders are ratiometric, meaning that their output voltage is influenced by the supply voltage. Some analog rangefinders (such as the SF/02) have their own internal voltage regulators so they are not ratiometric.

param.name: RNGFND_PWRRNG
param.documentation: This parameter sets the estimated terrain distance in meters above which the sensor will be put into a power saving mode (if available). A value of zero means power saving is not enabled

param.humanName: Distance (in cm) from the range finder to the ground
param.name: RNGFND_GNDCLEAR
param.documentation: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.

param.name: RNGFND_ADDR
param.documentation: This sets the bus address of the sensor, where applicable. Used for the LightWare I2C sensor to allow for multiple sensors on different addresses. A value of 0 disables the sensor.

param.name: RNGFND_POS_X
param.documentation: X position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

param.name: RNGFND_POS_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

param.name: RNGFND_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the first rangefinder in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

param.name: RNGFND_ORIENT
param.documentation: Orientation of rangefinder

param.name: RNGFND2_TYPE
param.documentation: What type of rangefinder device that is connected

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_MAVG
param.documentation: Sets the number of historic range results to use for calculating the current range result. When MAVG is greater than 1, the current range result will be the current measured value averaged with the N-1 previous results

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_MEDF
param.documentation: Sets the window size for the real-time median filter. When MEDF is greater than 0 the median filter is active

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_FRQ
param.documentation: Sets the repetition frequency of the ranging operation in Hertz. Upon entering the desired frequency the system will calculate the nearest frequency that it can handle according to the resolution of internal timers.

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_AVG
param.documentation: Sets the number of pulses to be used in multi-pulse averaging mode. In this mode, a sequence of rapid fire ranges are taken and then averaged to improve the accuracy of the measurement

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_THR
param.documentation: Sets the system sensitivity. Larger values of THR represent higher sensitivity. The system may limit the maximum value of THR to prevent excessive false alarm rates based on settings made at the factory. Set to -1 for automatic threshold adjustments

param.name: RNGFND2_WSP_BAUD
param.documentation: Desired baud rate

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_MAVG
param.documentation: Sets the number of historic range results to use for calculating the current range result. When MAVG is greater than 1, the current range result will be the current measured value averaged with the N-1 previous results

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_MEDF
param.documentation: Sets the window size for the real-time median filter. When MEDF is greater than 0 the median filter is active

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_FRQ
param.documentation: Sets the repetition frequency of the ranging operation in Hertz. Upon entering the desired frequency the system will calculate the nearest frequency that it can handle according to the resolution of internal timers.

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_AVG
param.documentation: Sets the number of pulses to be used in multi-pulse averaging mode. In this mode, a sequence of rapid fire ranges are taken and then averaged to improve the accuracy of the measurement

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_THR
param.documentation: Sets the system sensitivity. Larger values of THR represent higher sensitivity. The system may limit the maximum value of THR to prevent excessive false alarm rates based on settings made at the factory. Set to -1 for automatic threshold adjustments

param.name: RNGFND3_WSP_BAUD
param.documentation: Desired baud rate

param.name: RSSI_TYPE
param.documentation: Radio Receiver RSSI type. If your radio receiver supports RSSI of some kind, set it here, then set its associated RSSI_XXXXX parameters, if any.

param.name: RSSI_ANA_PIN
param.documentation: This selects an analog pin where the receiver RSSI voltage will be read.

param.name: RSSI_PIN_LOW
param.documentation: This is the voltage value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a lower value than RSSI_PIN_HIGH.

param.name: RSSI_PIN_HIGH
param.documentation: This is the voltage value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a higher value than RSSI_PIN_LOW.

param.name: RSSI_CHANNEL
param.documentation: The channel number where RSSI will be output by the radio receiver (5 and above).

param.name: RSSI_CHAN_LOW
param.documentation: This is the PWM value in microseconds that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL when the signal strength is the weakest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a lower value than RSSI_CHAN_HIGH.

param.name: RSSI_CHAN_HIGH
param.documentation: This is the PWM value in microseconds that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL when the signal strength is the strongest. Since some radio receivers put out inverted values from what you might otherwise expect, this isn't necessarily a higher value than RSSI_CHAN_LOW.

param.name: SCHED_DEBUG
param.documentation: Set to non-zero to enable scheduler debug messages. When set to show "Slips" the scheduler will display a message whenever a scheduled task is delayed due to too much CPU load. When set to ShowOverruns the scheduled will display a message whenever a task takes longer than the limit promised in the task table.

param.name: SCHED_LOOP_RATE
param.documentation: This controls the rate of the main control loop in Hz. This should only be changed by developers. This only takes effect on restart. Values over 400 are considered highly experimental.

param.name: SERIAL0_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used on the USB console. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL0_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the console.

param.name: SERIAL1_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the Telem1 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL1_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used on the Telem1 port. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL2_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the Telem2 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL2_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate of the Telem2 port. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL3_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol Serial 3 (GPS) should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL3_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used for the Serial 3 (GPS). The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL4_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol Serial4 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL4_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used for Serial4. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL5_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol Serial5 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL5_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used for Serial5. The APM2 can support all baudrates up to 115, and also can support 500. The PX4 can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support on APM2 and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERVO_AUTO_TRIM
param.documentation: This enables automatic servo trim in flight. Servos will be trimed in stabilized flight modes when the aircraft is close to level. Changes to servo trim will be saved every 10 seconds and will persist between flights.

param.name: SERVO_RATE
param.documentation: This sets the default output rate in Hz for all outputs.

param.name: SERVO10_MIN
param.documentation: minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO10_MAX
param.documentation: maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO10_TRIM
param.documentation: Trim PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO10_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse servo operation. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this output channel.

param.name: SERVO10_FUNCTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this servo. Seeing this to Disabled(0) will setup this output for control by auto missions or MAVLink servo set commands. any other value will enable the corresponding function

param.name: SERVO_BLH_MASK
param.documentation: Enable of BLHeli pass-thru servo protocol support to specific channels. This mask is in addition to motors enabled using SERVO_BLH_AUTO (if any)

param.name: SERVO_BLH_AUTO
param.documentation: If set to 1 this auto-enables BLHeli pass-thru support for all multicopter motors

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TEST
param.documentation: Setting SERVO_BLH_TEST to a motor number enables an internal test of the BLHeli ESC protocol to the corresponding ESC. The debug output is displayed on the USB console.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TMOUT
param.documentation: This sets the inactivity timeout for the BLHeli protocol in seconds. If no packets are received in this time normal MAVLink operations are resumed. A value of 0 means no timeout

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TRATE
param.documentation: This sets the rate in Hz for requesting telemetry from ESCs. It is the rate per ESC. Setting to zero disables telemetry requests

param.name: SERVO_BLH_DEBUG
param.documentation: When set to 1 this enabled verbose debugging output over MAVLink when the blheli protocol is active. This can be used to diagnose failures.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_OTYPE
param.documentation: When set to a non-zero value this overrides the output type for the output channels given by SERVO_BLH_MASK. This can be used to enable DShot on outputs that are not part of the multicopter motors group.

param.name: SERVO_SBUS_RATE
param.documentation: This sets the SBUS output frame rate in Hz.

param.name: SERVO_VOLZ_MASK
param.documentation: Enable of volz servo protocol to specific channels

param.documentation: Y position of the camera in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

param.humanName: Visual odometry camera Z position offset
param.name: VISO_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the camera in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

param.name: VISO_ORIENT
param.documentation: Visual odometery camera orientation

param.documentation: WheelEncoder counts per full revolution of the wheel

param.documentation: Wheel radius in meters

param.documentation: X position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

param.documentation: Y position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

param.name: WENC_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the center of the wheel in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

param.name: WENC_PINB

param.name: WENC2_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the center of the second wheel in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.
